column12: How would you rate your financial risk-taking behavior, on a scale from 1-7.
column13: You have been given $100. You can invest any part of this money in a risky asset. If the investment is successful, the risky asset returns 2.5 times the amount invested with a probability of one-half and nothing with a probability of one-half. You can also choose not to invest at all, in which case you will keep the money you have. How much would you like to invest? (write amount in dollars)

column6: Yes, entirely
column7: Given the expected value of the dividend of the stock and how much the interest rate on cash was, the stock's fair price was 14. So initially, I decided I would not buy over 14 and would only sell above 14. I ended up selling my stocks pretty quickly as the prices went up. It was clear that the price was roughly going to go up before going down before of the fixed by-back price (or maybe just stay up if nobody managed to sell before the end, as the buy-back was 14). As I didn't know if on the way up the price was going to be monotonic or oscillate a bit, at some point I placed some buy orders for maximum 1 stock around 30 (when the price was already close to 40 I think, around turn 10 or so maybe), hoping that I could maybe make some more money if I could sell back later. But this didn't happen, the price kept going up around 50, and so I decided I would just "sleep" on my cash until the end. As the price started going down very rapidly in the last round, I placed some buy orders around 13 (hoping some people may panic and didn't understand the buy-back was at 14), but that did not happen and the price stabilized around 16-17.
column8:
Regarding the instruction, I think they were rather clear, except for the reward for the forecasting which I missed or maybe read too rapidly. Maybe you could do a live presentation (or record a short video) to present orally the rules before.
The interface takes a little bit to get used to to place the buy and sell orders, but it was fine for me after a while. The time was a little short in general.
The forecast 4 rounds ahead was a little tedious at some point, maybe because of the interface wit which it was hard to pick exactly a price.
The risk elicitation task was my least favorite, as it felt very repetitive (and not fun like the trading for instance, where interactive stuff is happening). Also the time for it was a little short, and I think there might have been a bug in mine as I would sometimes have to chose between "do you prefer 100% chances 9$ or do you prefer 20$ with 100% chances", where of course I'd pick the latter

column8: The buy/sell order grid was pretty unwieldly.  I would prefer to type that in or some other system.

column6: Yes, but partially, I understood more as I continued trading
column7: Buying low and selling high. I'm pretty sure this is a common practice, you obviously want to make the highest returns as possible without losing much money. At first I spent no money until I got a considerable pool of money to spend on. After that, I'd buy maybe 2-3 shares every round until I held a fair amount and then sold considerably later.
column8: The time to enter forecasts and trading should maybe be 5-10 seconds longer. I understand this is a fast paced test, but including just a few more seconds could make the results completely different than the test we just took.

column8: I felt like a few more seconds to enter a forecast would have helped me a lot. There were a few turns where I wasn't able to enter all my predictions and I felt rushed.

column7: When I noticed the stock market start to drop, I tried to sell my stocks as fast as possible to maximize my cash at the end. I had to drop more and more because I kept overestimating the market price/price at which I could sell my stocks. I tried to buy more stocks early on but was hesitant. Not while trading but for the risk elicitation, I tried to choose not super risky lotteries, but if the ratio was high enough with an above 50% chance of getting the higher reward, I almost always chose that option over the other.

column6: Yes, entirely
column7: I went all in with shares in the first or second round. Actually,I  might have left a little cash to build up some cash reserves in the first 5 rounds. But I remember that at least from Round 5, I started buying every time I collected enough for a single share. I knew that it was essential to buy-in before Round 10. I had concerns that the peak would happen around Round 15, but I jumped the gun a bit. I could have held out longer for about 12% higher sale prices, but I wanted to unload my entire holdings before the peak. I was concerned that if the market fell flat, then finding a buyer would become increasingly difficult and I might have to sacrifice more than I might stand to gain by holding out for those final few points. I think I was all cash by Round 20 and I collected only from the 5% interest each round.
column8:
It seemed redundant to offer the text instructions so far away from the video instructions. It would have been nice to have those on the same page so that after completing the video, the text was available for quick reference. 

The Google docs pre-survey within the experiment tab seemed unusual. This was a minor inconvenience because it required more scrolling rather than having an entire tab's worth of view. 

If I could suggest an improvement to the dashboard, I felt that the experiment could be more exciting if there were a scoreboard so that players could know their standing in terms of total net worth. It was nice to play with other users, but the interactions felt quite empty. This is just wishful thinking because I find that competition brings out the best in my performance. I would settle for a final scoreboard so that I could learn my relative performance on the final screen.
